bibl.title: Letter from W.Z. Morrison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 20, 1940

div1.p: Morrison regrets that he cannot attend the ceremony and remembers fondly the time he spent with Hench when Hench was young.

div1.head: Letter from W.Z. Morrison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 20, 1940
div1.opener:
Wooster, Ohio,
October 20, 1940
P. S. Hench, M.D.,
Rochester,
Minn.
My dear Philip,
div1.p:
I wish that I could impersonate and repre-
sent your father at Washington, Pa. this week end at the
various functions in connection with the Founders' Day Ex-
ercises. That of course I can not do. Nevertheless I can not
but feel the satisfaction and joy which he would have had
were he alive today.

I regret that I can not be present in my own
person; the most that I can do is to try to picture the small
boy with whom I used to play bear on the floor, now not only
grown to the full stature of manhood but seated well up among
the leaders of his own profession, medicine. I am happy at
your success and wish for you still further distinction.

Next to my own boys, I believe that I have a
deeper and longer continued interest in Atcheson and yourself
than in any of the many boys I have known. In fact most of them
have faded completely from my memory. I suspect too that I abide
in the memory of a very few of them.

Just one year ago while on our way to visit Dr.
Sharpe in Blairstown, New Jersey, we passed through Easton and
both of us spoke of the many times we had heard your father
speak of Lafayette College and of his intense loyalty to it.
In fact if he supported an institution or possessed a friend
he seldom withdrew his support and would not be disposessed.
To me his Christian fortitude was wonderful.

There was some snow in this area yesterday; I
suppose winter will be upon us soon; I'm hoping that we'll have
a prolonged Indian summer continuing even to the old time Thanks-
giving. Which brings me to say that the politicians seem to be
warming up to their jobs. Where in the world is there such diver-
sity of opinion and yet such harmony after the fight is over.

We were in Pgh early in Sept. At that time
your mother seemed quite well. She maintains a lively interest in
political and church affairs. We were told today that Dr. Evans,
pastor of the Third church had had a call to Mark Matthews Church
in Seattle. Maybe he will not accept even though it would be a
big advancement in many ways.

You may not care to read all this. Even so I
can but remember how excited you used to become at my antics. Your
mother says “Uncle Billy” and so I like you to think.
